answers.a: A natural plant gum (E413) from Astragalus shrubs that forms a viscous, odorless gel in water and is used in foods as a thickener, stabilizer, and emulsifier.

Disperse the powder into cold water with good mixing (or preblend with sugar) and allow several hours to fully hydrate; typical food-use levels are about 0.1–0.5% to thicken and stabilize sauces, dressings, confectionery, and beverages, with good acid and heat tolerance.

answers.q: how to use gum tragacanth on leather
answers.a: Make a 1–3% solution in water, brush it onto cut edges, let it get tacky, then burnish; it binds and smooths the edge for a polished finish.

For food use, hydrate in cold water as a slow-swelling gel and use around 0.1–0.5% for thickening and stabilizing; in sugarcraft, knead a small amount into fondant (about 1–2 tsp per 500 g) and rest it to firm into gumpaste.

answers.q: gond katira what is it edible gum tragacanth
answers.a: Gond katira is edible gum tragacanth (E413) from Astragalus, often soaked to swell and used to thicken drinks and desserts. It is generally recognized as safe at normal food-use levels.
